I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  At the request of the Government of Sri Lanka, the Fact-Finding Mission from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) visited Sri Lanka on 22–26 August 20051 to formulate an advisory 
technical assistance (TA) for strengthening local government infrastructure financing through 
the Local Loans and Development Fund (LLDF).2 The strengthening of LLDF is much needed 
for  implementing  the  planned  ADB  Local  Government  Infrastructure  Improvement  Project 
(LGIIP).3 The  Mission  held  discussions  with  responsible  officials  of  agencies  concerned, 
including the Ministry of Finance and Planning (MoFP), Ministry of Provincial Councils and Local 
Government (MPCLG) and institutions under its purview, LLDF, and development partners. 
During the project preparatory TA for the LGIIP, the survey results from close to 200 local 
authorities were collected and local authority needs for infrastructure investment were analyzed. 
The present TA was developed on the basis of understanding reached during the Mission and 
the  Government’s  concurrence  with  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements; cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference (Appendix 1). 4  
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
2.  Need for Infrastructure Development. The Government places importance on steady 
economic growth, continuing macroeconomic stability, strong exports and imports, and inward 
foreign direct investment. Higher growth ensures greater government revenues and domestic 
savings. Higher levels of production, productivity, and wages mean stronger consumer spending 
and greater purchasing power and enhanced ability of households, businesses, and institutions 
to pay for high-quality urban infrastructure services and other local government services. There 
will be a desire and demand for much better natural and urban environments and a better 
quality of life.  Higher growth, personal incomes, purchasing power, and expectations from all 
citizens, business, and other stakeholders will place increasing pressures on governments to 
improve health, education, and the provision of other public goods. Appendix 2 gives the initial 
poverty and social analysis. 
 
3.  Local Loans and Development Fund. LLDF is a statutory body established under  
Local Loans and Development Ordinance No. 22 of 1916 and is one of the oldest financial 
establishments in Sri Lanka. The Ordinance has been amended from time to time.5 LLDF is 
administered by the local loans and development commissioners, and is a separate legal entity 
set up and operating under an Act of Parliament.  Currently functioning under MPCLG, LLDF’s 
prime objective is to meet the capital investment needs of the local authorities (LAs) through 
lending. LLDF advances loans to LAs at a concessionary or market-based rate of interest, 
depending on the type of investment, as well as to any person or body for any purpose of public 
utility subject to limits on the borrowing powers of the lender.

4.  Scarcity of Funds for Local Government Basic Services Development. LAs in Sri 
Lanka have been largely dependent on grants received from provincial councils (PCs) to meet 
their recurrent expenses; the balance is met out of own revenues. As a general trend, most LAs 
are unable to meet even the operation and maintenance (O&M) costs of existing assets as a 
large portion of their funds are diverted to pay for salaries and administration costs.6 LAs also 
depend on the national Government for assistance in undertaking capital projects, including 
through LLDF.7 Thus, LAs have little or no fund to take up new capital projects on their own. The 
situation has put a strain on existing infrastructure services, and the gap between demand and 
supply of infrastructure has been ever-widening. LAs are forced to look at alternative sources of 
financing to provide infrastructure, but their choices are currently restricted. LLDF is a major 
source where the private banking industry does not yet provide long-term infrastructure finance 
in Sri Lanka.  
 
5.  Need for Strengthening Institutional Capacity. Lack of capacity and low levels of 
expertise for project formulation and appraisal in LLDF have placed serious limitations on its 
effective functioning. Presently, the executive body consists of a chief executive officer, his 
deputy, and a few support staff. The team does not have a very high level of technical expertise 
appraising the technical and commercial viability of infrastructure-related project proposals, as 
well as LA financial capacity to repay the loan amount. LLDF lacks any operational guidelines 
on  project  evaluation,  lending  policies  and  criteria,  safeguard  policies,  human  resource 
development.  Low  staff  numbers  and  expertise  have  also  resulted  in  basic  treasury 
management, which is key to the success of any municipal financial funding agency. Beyond 
institutional strengthening measures, there is an urgent need for undertaking staff training, 
including knowledge transfer workshops.  
 
6.  Poor  Commercial  Orientation.  Most  loans  disbursed  by  LLDF  to  LA  have  been 
extended at a concessionary rate of interest. This practice has sent wrong signals to LAs, who 
have  become  complacent  in  loan  repayment.  LLDF  now  needs  to  move  toward  market 
mechanisms to ensure stronger financial discipline. Unlike other nodal funds in neighboring 
countries such as the Tamil Nadu Urban Development Fund (TNUDF), and Karnataka Urban 
Infrastructure  Development  Finance  Corporation  (KUIDFC)  in  India,  LLDF  has  not  been 
successful in marketing itself at the provincial and local levels and is also plagued by lack of 
commercial success of projects. Further, using LLDF loans for developing employment and 
revenue-generating projects has been limited.  
 
7.  Weak Enforcement. Traditionally, LLDF has been weak in terms of loan repayments 
and defaults. Although the LLDF Ordinance has built in a strong recovery mechanism to ensure 
no defaults in repayment of loans or misapplication of loans, there have been problems in 
exercising such powers due to reasons leading to a large number of defaults by LAs. These are 
the main reasons: (i) LLDF was brought into those projects merely as a debt collecting agency, 
and was not involved when loan applications were appraised; and (ii) the executing agencies of 
past ADB projects were different from MPCLG [e.g., Urban Development Authority (UDA)] that 
there was confusion in the decision-making authorities and responsibilities. LLDF made a total 
provision of SLRs14.3 million for bad debts clearly highlighting its inability to recover loan

8.  Lack of Alternative Sources of Financing. Unlike most other nodal funds in the region, 
LLDF is totally dependent on the Government for funding. There is a need to explore other 
options—like  accessing  commercial  banks,  capital  market  (bond  issues),  borrowings  from 
LAs— and develop credit enhancement measures like LA credit rating, setting up of escrow 
mechanisms, partial/full guarantees by PCs, debt service reserve funds, LLDF guarantees, etc. 
A diversified borrowing portfolio will make LLDF more responsive to market-driven borrowing 
and lending rates, and enable it to evolve into a long-term financial entity based on commercial 
principles. 
 
9.   Holistic Strengthening in Local Government Financing. It is clear that in Sri Lanka, 
financing of local government infrastructure needs a comprehensive review and strengthening. 
LLDF needs clear and transparent infrastructure project financing operational guidelines that 
include (i) definitions relevant to infrastructure financing; (ii) a thorough credit appraisal; (iii) 
minimum information requirements for a thorough appraisal, in particular the detailed feasibility 
report for the proposed infrastructure projects; (iv) separate risk assessment and risk mitigation 
strategies; (v) need for project escrow accounts for monitoring the repayment of debt, (vi) 
guarantee or collateral arrangements and security packages; (vii) special regulatory compliance 
measures in providing infrastructure project financing, such as exposure limits, maximum debt-
equity ratio for borrowers, maximum (10–20 years) duration of infrastructure loans; and (viii) 
other socioeconomic requirements. In addition, there is a need for the following: (i) further 
strengthening institutional capacity within provincial and local governments to develop, analyze, 
and  prepare  bankable  projects  and  to  structure  tender,  evaluate,  contract,  negotiate 
infrastructure/civil works projects; (ii) training and capacity building for officials to oversee and 
manage civil works project preparation, development, and oversight; (iii) standardized analytical 
tool kits for selecting, analyzing, structuring, tendering, evaluating, and negotiating projects; (iv) 
funds  to  pay  for  effective  private-sector  participation  in  project  preparation  to  bankable 
standards, and for transaction advisory services; (v) creating a long-term, fixed-rate Sri Lanka 
rupee-based financing for infrastructure investments.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
10.  The primary objective of the TA is to provide capacity building for LLDF to equip it with a 
necessary business plan, guidelines, operational manuals and various model loan agreements 
to be able to perform the functions and responsibilities of a nodal agency in providing loans to 
LAs for municipal infrastructure services. The TA also aims to help LLDF meet the disbursement 
conditions for the infrastructure8 financing component of ADB’s LGIIP, which is expected to 
begin in 2006. The main outputs of the TA will be (i) a code of conduct; (ii) a business plan, 
spanning at least 5 years that would cover the vision of becoming an independent full-fledged 
LA  nodal  fund,  including    human  resources  and  institutional  strengthening  to  expand  the 
services; (iii) operational guidelines in the immediate term for ADB’s LGIIP for appraising LA 
proposals  (lending  policy),  and  disbursing  and  repayment  procedures;  (iv)  model  legal 
documents,  including  model  loan  agreements  with  LAs,  PC  guarantee  agreement,  model 
performance agreement with LAs for a grant component; (v) organization chart and training 
                                                 
8  Infrastructure includes (i) water and sanitation; (ii) urban road, drainage; (iii) solid waste; and (iv) health clinic, 
library, parks.

4   
needs assessment for LLDF staff to meet these objectives; (vi) financial projections for 10 years 
commencing 2006; and (vii) future business expansion recommendations.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
11.  The TA will have three main components: (i) development of a strategic business plan to 
define the expansion of LLDF role of providing various financial means to assist LAs to avail 
financing for infrastructure; (ii) capacity building including workshops and study visits for LLDF 
management  and  staff,  central  government  agencies  (including  MoFP,  central  bank,  and 
MPCLG officials), PC and LA decision makers and financial management staff to learn about 
the potential for LA infrastructure financing; and (iii) assessment of LA needs and development 
of practical operational guidelines. 
 
12.  Component 1 will (i) set up a long-term vision of LLDF; how it would evolve into a full- 
fledged financing institution gradually expanding business services and financing tools, and (ii) 
develop  a  business  plan  for  LLDF  for  the  first  5  years  (2006–2010)  including  financial 
projections. Component 2 will examine best practices suitable for Sri Lanka in the area of 
specialized  financial  intermediaries  in  LA  infrastructure  and  services.  The  component  will 
include  workshops  to  disseminate  best  practices,9 on-the-job  training  for  LLDF  staff  on 
infrastructure project appraisal, study tours to actually learn from similar infrastructure financing 
institution’s daily work responsibilities and institutional arrangements with Indian cases (e.g., 
Karnataka, Tamil Nadu), and knowledge transfer and exchanges for key national/provincial and 
LLDF staff. Component 3 will include (i) preliminary assessment of infrastructure and services 
needs for 68 LAs to be targeted in the ADB LGIIP; and (ii) development of a detailed operational 
manual for LLDF including administrative structure, project appraisal guidelines, on safeguards 
policy, lending policy and criteria, human resources, and recruitment policy.  
 
13.  All proposed activities will be carried out in collaboration with MPCLG, LLDF, relevant 
government agencies, and the private sector that has potential for cooperating with LLDF 
mandates (e.g. chamber of commerce). An effort will also be made to create strong linkages 
with other capacity-building programs conducted by other funding agencies operating in Sri 
Lanka in the area of urban infrastructure and service delivery support.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $667,000 equivalent of which $392,800 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $274,200 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$107,200 equivalent in local currency. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the ADB TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent 
to $167,000 through the provision of office accommodation, utilities, remuneration of counterpart 
staff, local transportation, surveys, and workshops (See Appendix 3 for details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan).     
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  MPCLG will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and LLDF is the Implementing Agency 
(IA). LLDF will set up a TA implementing unit; appoint a manager10 for the unit; and provide

office space, furniture, equipment, and counterpart staff for the TA consultants as necessary. 
MPCLG will ensure that the following are closely involved in the TA, and that their concerns are 
fully considered:  MoFP, External Resources Department (ERD), National Planning Department 
(NPD), Finance Commission, Ministry of Urban Development and Water Supply [(UDA and 
National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB)], National Physical Planning Department 
and provincial chief secretaries, chairpersons of the association of municipal councils, urban 
councils and pradeshiya sabhas (periurban area local authority). The Government will set up a 
TA steering committee (TASC), 11 with the Secretary MPCLG as chair to periodically review TA 
progress and resolve any issues that may arise. The TASC will have representatives from all 
the ministries and agencies mentioned in this para. including the chief secretaries of eight 
provinces.12   
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months from April to September, 2006 through an 
international consulting firm. The consulting team (with person-months in parentheses) will have 
the  following  international  consultants  with  total  input  of  15  person-months:  (i)  municipal 
infrastructure finance specialist/team leader (6), (ii) capacity building specialist (4), (iii) financial 
analyst (3), and (iv) legal specialist (2). The domestic consultants will provide 15 person-months 
of input: (i) municipal infrastructure engineer (6), (ii) financial management specialist (3), (iii) 
capacity  building/training  expert  (4),  plus  drawdown  support  provision  of  2  person-months 
(covering social development and  safeguards issues). All consultants will be selected and 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. Terms of 
reference for the consulting services are in Appendix 4. The simplified technical proposal format 
and the quality and cost-based selection method will be used. Office equipment will be procured 
by the respective consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. After the 
Project, the equipment will be handed over and retained by LLDF. 
 
17.  The  consultants  will  submit  short  monthly  progress  reports  summarizing  activities, 
issues, and constraints for the duration of the TA. In addition, three major reports will be 
submitted. An inception report, to be submitted no later than 3 weeks after fielding of the 
consultants, will provide a detailed work program and establish time-bound outputs. A draft final 
report will be submitted 10 weeks after inception. The Government and ADB will give comments 
on the draft final report. The final report will be submitted within 3 weeks after receipt of 
comments from ADB review.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for Strengthening Local Government Infrastructure Financing, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

ERD is to give guidance on overall external assistance, UDA and NWSDB on relevant infrastructure strategy, 
NPPD on national planning aspects.  
12  ADB members may attend steering committee meetings if the review mission coincides with the meetings. Minutes

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka:  
 
Using the national poverty linea the proportion of the Sri Lankan population classified as poor was 22.7% in 2002. While 
income poverty in Sri Lanka appears to be low, nonincome poverty appears to be increasing. Basic urban infrastructure is 
generally in poor condition and deteriorating. Approximately 30% of the population lack access to safe drinking water, 
24% to safe sanitation facilities, and 56% to hygienic toilets. Inadequate sanitation is a leading cause of public health 
problems in communities. Poor and deficient basic urban infrastructure hinders improvement in the livelihood of poor 
communities. Studies identify that the poor from the lowest income quintile groups, estate plantation labor communities, 
small rural agricultural communities, and war-affected internally displaced persons are among those most seriously 
affected by a lack of basic urban infrastructure. Consumption data show that in the poorest quintile (average monthly 
household consumption of SLRs821) only 61% have access to safe drinking water compared with the richest quintile with 
89% having access; only 55% of the poorest quintile have access to safe sanitation compared with 89% in the richest, 
and only 84% of the poorest quintile have access to latrines compared with 94% in the richest. 
 
The disparity in household incomes is growing. The Gini concentration ratiob increased from 0.43 in 1980 to 0.47 in 2002. 
Income varies widely between urban and rural areas with average monthly household income in the rural areas of 
SLRs11,712 (2002)—only half of its urban counterpart SLRs22,420 (2002). Intraprovincial inequality is high: the average 
household monthly income of the poorest province of Sabaragamuwa (SLRs8,439) is only 48% that of its Western 
Province counterpart (SLRs17,732). Basic urban infrastructure is unequally distributed. This exacerbates the slow 
economic growth and social development experienced by poor regions. The higher degrees of poverty experienced in 
Sabaragamuwa, Uwa, and conflict-affected northeast provinces illustrates this. Most of these areas are considered rural 
and are administered by rural local authorities (LAs) or pradeshiya sabhas. More than 80% of Sri Lanka’s poor live in 
pradeshiya sabahs. While national average levels of access to basic urban infrastructure, access to safe sanitation, 
drinking water, toilets, and health services is low, these are even poorer in pradeshiya sabahs, especially when compared 
with that in urban and relatively developed regions such as Western Province. 
 
Improving basic urban infrastructure will result in directly reducing nonincome poverty, and is likely to result in indirectly 
reducing income poverty through human development and associated economic growth. The Project is designed to assist 
selected LAs in developing management capabilities, and strengthening capacity in the delivery of community-prioritized 
basic urban services. It will also improve and expand basic urban infrastructure and services particularly in the categories 
of (i) community water supply and sanitation, (ii) access and LA roads, (iii) solid waste management, (iv) drainage 
improvements, and (v) institutional infrastructure (health, education, common community facilities, and administrative 
facilities).  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                     Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Nationally, the poverty headcount does not appear very high at 22.7%. However, large differences in poverty are found 
across the country. The poverty levels for rural and urban populations for example are 24.7% and 7.9%, respectively. 
Some differences are found in income inequality between rural and urban areas with Gini concentration ratios of 0.46 and 
0.48, respectively. In 2002, poverty headcounts in the region varied. The lowest level of poverty was in the Western 
Province, where the poverty headcount was only 9.2%. In comparison, the poverty in Uva was 31.8%, Sabaragamuwa 
28.9%, Southern 23.6%, North Western 22.3%, Central 20.8%, and North Central 18.1%.c  When examined by district, the 
variability increases further with poverty headcounts ranging from 32.4% in Moneragalato 5.0% in Colombo; and Gini 
concentration ratios ranging from 0.56 in Moneragala to 0.40 in Nuwara Eliya, Hambantota, and Polonnaruwa.  
 
Aside from the relatively high levels of poverty and income inequality in certain districts and provinces, the income 
structure is such that a large number of the population are near-poverty. When poverty is defined using two poverty lines, 
1996 data show that a higher poverty line of SLRs950 classifies 26% as poor; while a lower poverty line of SLRs791 
classifies 19% as poor.d  This shows that although the number of core poor may not be so high, a large number of near-
poor are highly vulnerable. This is significant considering the high dependence on the primary sector, and one event such 
as a natural calamity can result in poverty due to loss of productive assets.  
 
This vulnerability is further aggravated by the lack of basic urban infrastructure. A high degree of nonincome poverty 
results from the lack of basic urban infrastructure; access varies widely across provinces and districts. Using water and

Appendix 2  9
sanitation as an example, while 95.8% of the population in Colombo have access to safe drinking water, only 58.6% of 
the population in Ratnapura have access.e Similarly 97.6% of the population in Matara have latrine facilities while only 
28.4% in Batticaloa have such facilities.  
 
A field-level analysis was conducted in 22 LAs through (i) information collection from LAs; (ii) key informant interviews in 
LAs; (iii) focus group discussions with stakeholders including subproject beneficiaries, community-based and other civic 
organizations,  and  basic  urban  service  providers;  (iv)  participatory  needs  assessment  aimed  at  identifying  basic 
infrastructure needs and priorities; (v) strengths-weaknesses-opportunities-threats analysis involving stakeholders; and 
(vi) questionnaire for potential beneficiaries. The analysis shows that poor households have very limited access to basic 
urban infrastructure. For example, the analysis shows that a third of the lowest-income households, with average monthly 
household incomes of less than SLRs1,000, have no access to safe drinking water. Of these low-income households only 
50% had access to sanitation.  
 
Participatory  assessment  identifies  improved  drinking  water  supply  and  access  roads  for  improved  economic 
opportunities as the most important needs of LAs, particularly in rural areas. Eight of 22 LAs surveyed (37%) identified 
water supply as their first priority while 18% identified access roads. The lack of access to safe drinking water required 
households to spend considerable time and effort in fetching water. This burden was especially pronounced for poor 
households and female members of these households. Public health issues arise from the use of unprotected water 
sources for drinking—this increases the burden on poor households. Inadequate access roads limit the marketing of 
produce from poor communities. The lack of access roads also increases the difficulties in accessing basic urban 
infrastructure such as health centers and schools. Children in poor communities walk several kilometers to attend school. 
The participatory needs assessment also identified the need for sanitation, drainage, improved solid waste management, 
and improved institutional infrastructure.  
 
By strengthening LA capacity and providing basic urban infrastructure, an enabling environment will be created for 
delivering basic infrastructure services in a sustained manner. The Project’s LA selection criteria ensure that the Project 
will consider and prioritize LAs where poverty is high and basic infrastructure services are lacking. The Project provides 
direct benefits through increased access to basic urban infrastructure and services, and enhances the potential for 
investments and economic growth in poor areas. Key benefits expressed by stakeholders include enabling small 
producers to market products without experiencing hardships and exploitation from agents and reduced social exclusion 
with increased transportation and mobility from access roads; increased time for productive labor for income generation; 
and improved health from improved access to drinking water. Solid waste subprojects will provide better waste disposal 
facilities to nearly half of the LA population. Water supply and sanitation subprojects are aimed at serving at least one fifth 
of the LA population currently severely constrained due to lack of access to or the poor quality of current infrastructure 
and services. The Project, through the provision of basic urban infrastructure and  services,  will promote human 
development  envisioned  to  enable  the  poor  to  take  advantage  of  potential  social  and  economic  resources  and 
opportunities. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis:                           Yes     No 
 
Extensive community consultation was undertaken in 22 representative LAs. This included (i) information collection from 
LAs; (ii) key informant interviews in 22 LAs; (iii) focus group discussions in 22 LAs involving 357 stakeholders such as 
subproject beneficiaries (including potentially vulnerable groups such as poor and low income groups); nongovernment, 
community-based, and other civic organizations; and basic urban service providers; (iv) participatory needs assessment 
aimed at identifying basic infrastructure needs and priorities through 16 group discussions; (v) analysis of strengths, 
weaknesses, opportunities, and threats in 12 LAs involving stakeholders; and (vi) questionnaire for 234 potential 
beneficiaries. These activities aimed at ascertaining stakeholders’ response to improved infrastructure services; the 
communities’ needs and demands; affordability; and impacts on women, indigenous people, estate plantation workers, 
different ethnicities, small farmers, and other disadvantaged groups. Community and stakeholder consultations reveal the 
following: (i) better access roads will give the poor access to services, decrease travel time, and provide better access to 
markets and educational facilities; this is perceived as a major project benefit; (ii) safe drinking water saves time for 
women for additional income-earning opportunities, and improve health and hygienic conditions; these are perceived to 
be major project benefits; (iii) communities are prepared to pay for improved services, and the operation and maintenance 
of subprojects; and (iv) they perceive that increased access to services will reduce poverty and improve quality of life. 
 
Is there a participation strategy:                                  Yes     No 
 
Much of the Project will be implemented through stakeholder participation and consultations using a community-driven 
approach (including United Nations Development Programme and United Nations-Habitat Sustainable Cities Program). 
Subproject identification, formulation, design, and selection will be carried out through community consultations. During 
the social analysis, community preferences were identified. Local participation in the subprojects through active civic and

10    Appendix 2 
community-based  organizations  will  be  encouraged.  During  the  field  analysis  some  active  local  nongovernment 
organizations were found to be engaged in solid waste management, recycling, and implementation of low-cost sanitation 
and  toilet  facilities  in  some  LAs.  Beneficiary  participation  and  the  involvement  of  all  stakeholders  including 
nongovernment, civic, and community-based organizations will promote a bottom- up participatory process, proven 
effective and successful in other ongoing aid-supported projects in the sector.   
 
D.  Gender and Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
National indicators show that women in Sri Lanka have an equivalent status to men in terms of education (literacy rate for 
women is 89.2% compared with men at 92.3%; net enrolment ratio for girls is 95.6% for ages 6–10 and 97.1% for boys), 
health (life expectancy is 76.4 for women, 71.7 for men; infant mortality is 15.6 per 1,000 girls, 22.6 per 1,000 boys), and 
poverty (percentage of poor households headed by women is 21.5% compared with 23.0% for households headed by 
men). However, the labor force participation rate for women is only 33.6% compared with 67.9% for men, and female 
professional and technical workers comprise only 22.9% of total workers. 
 
Focus group discussions and field investigations show that in the project areas, women bear the primarily responsibility 
for managing the domestic environment. Their tasks include water collection and ensuring solid waste disposal. The 
Project will benefit women largely through reduced time for collecting water and other household chores related to 
disposing of solid waste. This reduces their burden from manual work, increases time for productive activities, which will 
raise household income and potentially their status in the household, and increase social and leisure time. Other 
externally supported projects (including United Nations Development Programme and United Nations-Habitat Sustainable 
Cities Program) in Sri Lanka have consistently demonstrated that women in poverty reduction programs involving water 
supply, sanitation, and microfinance have elicited women’s active participation and benefited women. Other benefits from 
the Project are likely to benefit women and men equally. Subproject design will ensure women are provided equal access 
to potential skills training and employment opportunities, and promote women’s active participation in community-based 
basic urban infrastructure provision and management.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Each consultant will work with the team in developing all outputs. The team leader and 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer, however, may revise or augment the tasks 
outlined here, as required, to comply with ADB guidelines and procedures, and to improve the 
quality of the overall project.  
 
2.  The tasks are to be carried out in close cooperation with the Government, and extensive 
consultation needs to take place to ensure transfer of know-how and full ownership of the 
processes and documents by the ministries and local authorities concerned. Throughout the 
process, the consulting team will thoroughly review and build on the extensive work that has 
already been done by other external assistance and government agencies in the sector.   
 
A.  Municipal Infrastructure Finance Specialist/Team Leader (international, 6 person-   
months) 
 
3.  The consultant should have strong economic and financial skills; an understanding of the 
design, establishment, operation, evaluation and strengthening of public funds for financing 
urban infrastructure; and knowledge of the operations and activities of municipal development 
funds. Knowledge of the region and prior experience of working in Sri Lanka in the relevant 
sector will be an advantage. 
 
4.  As  team  leader,  the  specialist  will  organize  and  manage  the  consulting  team  and 
coordinate the overall TA. He/she will be accountable for the quality and timeliness of all 
deliverables, and ensure that all components are clearly and concisely documented to the full 
satisfaction of the ADB project team and the Executing Agency. The team leader will also be 
responsible for ensuring that the final outputs prepared through the TA are complete, cohesive, 
financially  and  economically  viable,  and  in  full  compliance  with  all  pertinent  ADB  and 
Government policies and guidelines. He/she will consider potential synergies with other ADB 
projects,  as  well  as  initiatives  by  the  Government  and  other  development  agencies.  The 
consultant’s tasks will include the following:  
 
(i)  Review the existing fiscal framework of the Local Loans and Development Fund 
(LLDF) including existing financial management responsibilities and procedures, 
and assess the decision-making structure and procedures as well as LLDF’s 
financial soundness. 
(ii)  Analyze the existing loan portfolio of local authorities (LAs) and undertake a LA 
needs assessment while identifying sectors for priority lending that will result in 
infrastructure  development  and  pro-poor  reforms.  Needs  assessment  will 
specifically include preliminary identification of infrastructure and service needs 
for the 68 LAs qualified to participate in the first phase of the Local Government 
Infrastructure Improvement Project (LGIIP).  
(iii)  Study and analyze existing treasury management systems of LLDF and give 
recommendations for improving treasury management functions and systems, 
especially for un-lent funds in LLDF. 
(iv)  Take the key responsibility for developing detailed operational manuals for LLDF 
covering administrative structure, project appraisal guidelines, safeguard policies, 
lending policy and criteria, human resource and recruitment policy, and other 
areas that may be identified as part of the project.  
(v)  Undertake and coordinate with the remaining consultants the development of a 
timeline  and  strategy  for  establishing  a  clear  policy  and  vision  statement 
(medium- and long-term) for transforming LLDF into a full-fledged nodal funding

14 Appendix 4 
agency gradually expanding business services and financing tools across the 
country. 
(vi)  Undertake and coordinate the development of a business plan for LLDF for the 
first 5-year period (2006–2010). The business plan will focus on developing a 
marketing plan, among others.  
(vii)  Support LLDF in conducting workshops, which support LLDF’s effort to market 
itself and make its functions widely known to LAs, and build demand on the loan 
application pipeline, and prepare necessary guidelines, literature, reading and 
marketing material. 
(viii)  Support LLDF in dialogues and information dissemination with Government and 
stakeholders. 
(ix)  Explore alternate low-cost finance options and increased borrowing powers of 
LLDF  (long  term)  to  tap  funds  from  the  capital  market,  commercial  banks, 
through  debentures,  and  other  sources;  and  liase  with  the  LLDF  financial 
advisors  in  exploring  alternate  credit  enhancement  measures  like  provincial 
council guarantees, escrow of LA revenues, debt service reserve funds, etc., for 
future loans.   
(x)  Review  recommendations  made  by  the  Commission  of  Inquiry  on  Local 
Government  Reforms  1999  and  outputs,  wherever  possible,  and  ensure 
harmonization of the same with other aid-funded efforts in the country. 
 
B.  Capacity Building Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
5.  The specialist will primarily focus on developing adequate training program/tools for the 
institutional-strengthening  and  capacity-building  component  of  the  ensuing  Project.  He/she 
should have knowledge of the operations and activities of local governments training programs 
and manuals. Knowledge of the region will be an advantage. Specific tasks are as follows: 
 
(i)  Undertake  training  needs/skill  assessment  to  upgrade  the  skills  of  staff  and 
identify  training  centers  and  resources  in  Sri  Lanka  as  well  as  in  the 
region/neighboring countries where skill may be upgraded.  
(ii)  Examine existing human resource development policies, and assist the team 
leader  in  developing  operational  guidelines  on  administrative  structure  and 
training as well as a human resource and recruitment policy for LLDF.  
(iii)  Identify  and  examine  best  practices  suitable  for  Sri  Lanka  in  the  area  of  a 
specialized financial nodal agency providing LA infrastructure and services. 
(iv)  Identify  and  structure  capacity  building  and  training  exercises  including 
classroom  training,  best  practices  workshops,  study  visits,  short-term 
international training in the region for key national/provincial and LLDF staff. 
Foreign experience sharing will include Tamil Nadu Urban Development Fund 
(TNUDF),  Karnataka  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Finance  Corporation 
(KUIDFC) in India.   
(v)  Review government training institutions (and training programs) where LLDF staff 
are being/can be trained and identify their strengths, weaknesses and gaps, and 
identify aid-funded training programs where linkages for training of LLDF staff 
can be created.  
 
C.  Financial Analyst (international, 3 person-months) 
 
6.  The financial analyst should be experienced in municipal finance, financial analysis, 
accounting and budgeting systems, and related areas. He/she should have a professional 
qualification in finance. Experience of having worked with long-term municipal funds in the 
region will be an advantage. The analyst will be responsible for these tasks:

Appendix 4  15
 
 
(i)  Analyze  and  prepare  a  list  of  chronic  defaulters  and  develop  a  strategy  for 
recovery and future lending. 
(ii)  Conduct local budget analysis, which includes overall revenue and expenditure 
structures, local taxing power, and intergovernmental transfers (block grants and 
matching grants). The result will be a basis for proposed future (a) collateral 
arrangement, (b) regulatory compliance measures (exposure limit, etc.), and (c) 
provision requirements. 
(iii)  Ensure the long-term sustainability of LLDF as a LA infrastructure nodal funding 
agency by setting up a revolving fund structure and combining development and 
commercial principles for the revolving fund. 
(iv)  Make a financial analysis and projections of LLDF for the next 5 years as part of 
the business plan and a long-term (10–15 years) business plan. 
(v)  Assist  LLDF  in  preparing  of  detailed  performance  improvement  measures, 
targets, and future fund flow. 
(vi)  Assist in preparing the detailed operation manual guidelines in the areas of 
appraisal, financial statements, financial and economic analyses, etc. 
 
D.  Legal Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
7.  The legal specialist will assist the team leader and the capacity building specialist. The 
detailed  tasks  to  be  undertaken,  with  extensive  consultation  and  cooperation  with  the 
Government of Sri Lanka, ADB, and other stakeholders, will include, but may not be restricted to 
the following:  
 
(i)  Assist the team leader in identifying outstanding pieces of the legal framework 
and personnel management that are needed to improve the capacity of LLDF to 
operate more efficiently. 
(ii)  Assist  in  developing  guidelines  and  systems  required  for  stringent  project 
appraisal, loan documentation, monitoring, and recoveries, etc. 
(iii)  Identify legal gaps, if any, in areas of ownership, lending, accessing alternative 
sources of financing, documentation and procurement, disbursement, and loan 
recovery, etc., and identifying ways to plug these gaps.  
(iv)  Develop a strategy for engagement with provinces, LAs, and legal recourse for 
debt recovery; discuss them with the Board of Commissioners and other key 
stakeholders for their approval.  
(v)  Assist the team leader in developing a detailed operational manual for LLDF 
especially on safeguard policies, lending policies and criteria, procurement and 
legal documentation including a model loan agreement, a model performance 
agreement,  a  model  guarantee  agreement,  administrative  structure,  and  any 
other area identified by the team leader.  
(vi)  Propose a strategy for addressing constraints identified, if any, in the existing 
legal framework of LLDF and LLDF-provincial council (PC)-LA cooperation (in 
areas such as prioritization of development needs and smooth fiscal transfer 
arrangements) in relation to financing of basic urban infrastructure. 
 
E.  Municipal Infrastructure Engineer (domestic, 6 person-months) 
 
8.  The engineer should hold an internationally recognized degree in civil engineering and 
other relevant area, and should have substantial experience in municipal and urban public 
health  engineering  in  Sri  Lanka.  Experience  of  working  on  aid-funded  projects  will  be  an 
advantage. The consultant will assist the team leader in developing guidelines for evaluating

16 Appendix 4 
detailed subproject reports as well as for monitoring subproject progress. Specific tasks would 
include the following: 
 
(i)  Examine and draw lessons from assessment guidelines and benchmarks for 
monitoring  the  implementation  of  similar  projects  including  the  ADB-funded 
Urban Development and Low Income Housing Project (UDLIHP),1 etc. 
(ii)  Assist the team leader in developing guidelines for evaluating detailed project 
report and benchmarks for monitoring.  
(iii)  Develop  criteria  for  technical  appraisal  and  environmental  compliance  of 
subprojects for funding by LLDF.  
(iv)  Establish  a  procedure  for  ongoing  monitoring,  operation  and  maintenance 
(O&M), and related implementation issues for subprojects financed by LLDF. 
(v)  Develop guidelines for structuring commercially viable infrastructure projects.   
(vi)  Assist the team leader in developing a detailed operational manual for LLDF 
including project appraisal guidelines, safeguard policies, and any other area 
identified by the team leader. 
 
F.  Financial/Economic Management Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant will have a recognized degree in finance and economics, experience in 
economic and infrastructure development in Sri Lanka, and experience in developing feasibility 
studies for projects funded by ADB or other funding agency. The consultant’s tasks will include 
the following:  
 
(i)  Assist the team leader and financial analyst.  
(ii)  Review present accounting, financial management, and control systems, and, 
based  on  an  examination  of  international  best  practices,  suggest  means  to 
improve financial management and control systems in LLDF.  
(iii)  Conduct local budget analysis, which includes overall revenue and expenditure 
structures, local taxing power, and intergovernmental transfers (block grants and 
matching  grants).  This  will  be  a  basis  for  proposed  future  (a)  collateral 
arrangements, (b) regulatory compliance measures (exposure limit, etc.), and (c) 
provision requirements. 
(iv)  Examine and draw lessons from a financial and economic feasibility study of a 
subproject in similar projects including the ADB-funded LGIIP, UDLIHP, etc., and 
based  on  the  findings,  refine  the  guidelines  and  assist  the  international 
consultant in developing a detailed operational manual for appraising projects.   
(v)  Assist in drawing up criteria for LLDF to assess LA financial viability. 
 
G.  Capacity Building/Training Specialist (domestic, 4 person-months) 
 
10.  The consultant should have experience in training and capacity building in Sri Lanka, 
exposure to training institutions and communication network in Sri Lanka, and experience with 
other aid-funded projects. The tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in assessing staff training needs and skills, and identifying training centers 
and resources in Sri Lanka where skill upgrading may be done. 
(ii)  Review the existing human resources policy of LLDF and other Government and 
similar organizations to effectively link the cadre system and actual post needs.

H.  Drawdown  Support─Social  Development  and  Environment  (domestic; 2 person-
months) 
 
11.  Environmental  Assessment. The consultants will provide LLDF with procedures to 
make an initial environmental examination and summary or environmental impact analysis for 
prospective infrastructure-related proposals in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy and 
Environmental  Guidelines  (2003),  as  well  as  Sri  Lanka’s  environmental  protection  agency 
(Central Environment Agency) regulations. The consultants will (i) assess positive and negative 
environmental  impacts  of  proposed  urban  social  infrastructure  and  services  in  relation  to 
location, design, construction, and O&M; (ii) propose mitigating measures and develop a full 
environmental monitoring plan; (iii) develop procedures for conducting consultations as per ADB 
requirements; and (iv) develop a model financial intermediary environment management plans 
for environmental sensitive subcomponents.  
 
12.  Social and Resettlement Assessment. The consultants will develop (i) procedures to 
assess a prospective project’s social impact, including patterns of water use, water costs, 
perception of the environment, income levels, and distribution, in accordance with Guidelines for 
Incorporation of Social Dimensions in ADB Operations; (ii) procedures to ascertain the number 
of indigenous people and minorities and their socioeconomic status and specific anticipated 
project impact on them, using among others, the checklist Categorization of Indigenous People 
and, if necessary, develop indigenous people development plans according to ADB’s Policy on 
Indigenous People; and (iii) based on ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development and assisted 
by ADB’s Gender Checklist for Water Supply and Sanitation and Gender Checklist on Urban 
Development Projects, procedures to assess local gender-related constraints and opportunities 
for development and formulate a gender action plan for the ensuing Project. 
 
13.  The consultants will apply ADB’s resettlement checklists to identify resettlement issues 
and ascertain the nature and degree of the LGIIP impacts on affected households. From the 
assessment,  the  consultants  will  develop  procedures  to  assess  resettlement  impacts,  in 
accordance with ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Handbook on Resettlement, a 
model resettlement plan, including (i) a review and assessment of key national policies, laws, 
and guidelines regarding land acquisition and compensation; (ii) how to identify and enumerate 
affected people (iii) how to ascertain relocation areas, compensation, and livelihood restoration; 
(iv) how to establish cutoff date and estimate financial resources, comparing with resources 
made available within the country; (v) how to provide options for relocating housing and other 
structures, including transfer to established new sites and options for livelihood restoration and 
mechanisms  for  addressing  grievances;  (vi)  how  to  define  institutional  responsibilities  for 
approving,  implementing,  managing,  financing,  and  monitoring  the  resettlement  plan, 
implementation  schedules,  capacity  building,  financial  plan  and  budgets,  and  internal  and 
external monitoring and evaluation of the resettlement plan.2
